qas.question: What can be seen in the newly electrified lines?
What can electrification of modern trains effect?
How can better service quality be achieved?
Electrification in passenger rail systems leads to insignificant jumps in what?

plausible_answers.text: general infrastructure and rolling stock overhaul / replacement

qas.question: What leads to decreasing service quality?
A "sparks effect" is often seen on old lines which are what?
Electric trains are often seen as less modern and what?
What is well established for routes that have been electrified for days?

context: Newly <b5_0>electrified<b5_0/> lines often show a <a0_0>"sparks effect"<a0_0/>, whereby electrification in passenger rail systems leads to significant jumps in <a1_0><b3_0>patronage / revenue<b3_0/><a1_0/>. The reasons may include electric trains being seen as more modern and <b6_0>attractive to ride<b6_0/>, faster and smoother service, and the fact that electrification often goes hand in hand with a <b4_0>general infrastructure and <a2_0>rolling stock overhaul / replacement<b4_0/><a2_0/>, which leads to better service quality (in a way that theoretically could also be achieved by doing similar upgrades yet without electrification). Whatever the causes of <b7_0>the sparks effect<b7_0/>, it is well established for numerous routes that have electrified over decades.
